question: You are a coding expert, please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the code you generate is executable and can be demonstrated. Please implement a food service menu file management system where chefs can upload new menu files (such as dish images and descriptions) through a front-end interface, and restaurant managers can review these menus. After approval, the menus will be displayed on the front-end for customers. The system should include menu category display functionality.

checklist.title: Is the front-end upload interface for chefs fully implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code implements a complete and user-friendly file upload interface for chefs, including file selection, preview, form validation, and progress indication. Check if it handles multiple file types (images, PDFs), supports drag-and-drop functionality, and provides clear feedback on upload status. Score 0 if upload functionality is missing, 5 if basic uploading exists but lacks validation or feedback, and 10 if the interface is comprehensive with all required features.

checklist.title: Is the menu review system for managers properly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate the management interface that allows restaurant managers to review, approve, reject, or request changes to submitted menu items. Check if it includes notification mechanisms, review status tracking, and comment functionality. The system should display pending items clearly and provide sorting/filtering options. Deduct 5 points if approval workflows are incomplete, 3 points if notification systems are missing, and 2 points if there's no audit trail of decisions. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the menu category display functionality properly implemented?
checklist.description: Assess whether the code implements a well-structured category system for menu items (e.g., appetizers, main courses, desserts) with proper hierarchical organization. Check if it includes features like category filtering, sorting options, and responsive display across different screen sizes. Deduct 5 points if categories are fixed and not dynamically manageable, 3 points if category filtering is missing, and 4 points if the category display is not responsive. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the customer-facing menu display interface properly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate the front-end interface that displays approved menus to customers. Check if it includes high-quality image rendering, proper information organization (prices, descriptions, ingredients, allergens), search functionality, and filtering options. The interface should be visually appealing and responsive. Deduct 3 points for missing search functionality, 4 points for poor image handling, and 5 points if the layout is not responsive. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as file upload failures, server disconnections, unauthorized access attempts, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Check if input validation is thorough and if the system handles edge cases like large file uploads or concurrent modifications. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these scenarios, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. AI-powered food photography enhancement 2. Automatic nutritional information calculation 3. Seasonal menu rotation system 4. Customer preference tracking for personalized recommendations). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple file upload components with overlapping functionality) 2. Function modules unrelated to restaurant menu management (e.g., a built-in social networking feature) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., unnecessary animations that slow down menu browsing). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating UI components, services, API calls), code organization, error handling patterns, and build process automation. Examine if the system uses appropriate design patterns for state management and data flow. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if the build process is not automated. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching (no more than 3 primary colors, with appropriate food-related color psychology) 2) Proper layout spacing (element spacing follows the 8px multiple principle) 3) Professional typography (menu items clearly hierarchical, descriptions readable). Deduct 3 points for cluttered menu layouts, 5 points for poor color combinations that don't complement food imagery, and 5 points for inconsistent typography across the application. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the dynamic effects conform to human perception characteristics: 1) Menu loading and filtering response â‰¤ 300ms 2) Transition animations between menu sections controlled between 300-500ms 3) Clear visual indication of selected categories and items. Check if image loading is optimized (lazy loading, proper compression). Deduct 5 points for menu transitions that freeze the interface, 3 points for jarring animations when switching categories, and 5 points for slow image loading without placeholders. The full score is 10 points.
